Award.AwardTitle: NEESR: Seismic Response of Shallow Underground Structures in Dense Urban Environments

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Shallow underground structures used for public transportation are a key component of sustainable cities. In dense urban environments, underground structures are often built near tall buildings. Although such buildings have the potential to alter ground motions in their vicinity and transmit significant forces to adjacent underground structures, the impact of these forces remains uncertain. This project will study the seismic response of temporary and permanent cut-and-cover box structures near mid- to high-rise buildings using a combination of centrifuge testing and numerical simulations. The NEES centrifuge facility at UC Davis will be used for these tests. The data from the tests will serve two purposes: first, to understand seismic soil-structure-underground structure-interaction (SSUSI), and second, to calibrate and improve numerical models. Nonlinear numerical simulations of centrifuge tests will help assess and improve the capabilities of existing numerical tools in capturing SSUSI and key loading mechanisms. Parametric studies using calibrated models will be conducted to make design recommendations. Data from this project will be archived and made available to the public through the NEES Project Warehouse/data repository.

This endeavor will provide engineers with well-calibrated predictive tools to more reliably characterize interactions between soil, foundation, structure, and shallow underground structure during earthquakes. A better understanding of these interactions will also advance research and practice for a range of underground facilities and critical lifelines including tunnels, pipelines, and utilities. As such, the findings of this project are an important step toward improving the resilience of our urban centers to earthquakes. This research project is a collaborative effort between the University of Colorado at Boulder, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and ARUP San Francisco. This study will also benefit from collaboration between researchers at NEES and Japan's E-Defense. In its outreach program, the project will recruit outstanding students from underrepresented groups in engineering in collaboration with NSF funded Colorado Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) and the Center for Broadening Opportunity through Leadership and Diversity (BOLD) at CU Boulder. This award is part of the National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program (NEHRP).

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Boulder
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Colorado

POR.DRECONTENT:
Shallow underground structures used for public transportation are a key component of sustainable cities. In dense urban environments, underground structures are often built near tall buildings. Although such buildings have the potential to alter ground motions in their vicinity and transmit significant forces to adjacent underground structures, the impact of these forces are uncertain. This project studied the seismic response of temporary and permanent cut-and-cover box structures near mid to highrise buildings using a combination of centrifuge testing and numerical simulations. The data from centrifuge tests served two purposes: first, to understand seismic soil-structure-underground structure-interaction (SSUSI), and second, to calibrate and improve numerical models. Nonlinear numerical simulations of centrifuge tests helped assess the capabilities of existing numerical tools in capturing SSUSI and key loading mechanisms.

A preliminary centrifuge experiment representing free-field soil conditions was first performed with the target soil relative density and the selected input ground motions in the first year of the project. Subsequently, six major centrifuge experiments were performed to evaluate the seismic response of a permanent and temporary underground structure in dry, medium-dense sand first independently without any building present, then adjacent to a midrise (12-stories) and a highrise (42-stories) building. In general, these experiments indicated a notable increase in seismic earth pressures induced on the underground structure adjacent to tall buildings, which must be considered in design. These additional seismic forces were found to correlate with the base shear of the adjacent building. Data from these experiments was archived and made available to the public through the NEES Project Warehouse/data repository, and the results summarized in a series of M.S. theses, Ph.D. dissertations, and peer-reviewed conference and journal publications.

In parallel and complementary to the detailed planning, execution, and analysis of experimental data, nonlinear numerical simulations of the centrifuge tests were performed. The comparisons between numerical and experimental results demonstrated that modern numerical modeling tools can reasonably predict the seismic response of the soil-structure-underground structure system and their interactions. The numerical simulations exhibited behavior similar to the centrifuge tests in terms of the shape and magnitude of the dynamic earth pressure distribution and the impact of the adjacent building on seismic displacements and earth pressures imposed on the underground structure. The behavior exhibited in the centrifuge and numerical models in this study are distinctly different than those predicted by many of the common, simplified analysis methods used in engineering design. This indicates that it may be necessary to employ numerical modeling in the design of underground structures in the presence of other structures or with complex geometries and loading conditions. Importantly, modern numerical tools have greatly reduced the barriers to application of large complex numerical modeling in engineering design.

This research provides engineers with well-calibrated predictive tools to more reliably characterize interactions between soil, foundation, structure, and shallow underground structure during earthquakes. A better understanding of these interactions will also advance research and practice for a range of underground facilities and critical lifelines including tunnels, pipelines, and utilities. As such, the findings of this project are an important step toward improving the resilience of our urban centers to earthquakes. This research project is a collaborative effort between the University of Colorado Boulder, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and ARUP San Francisco. This study also benefitted from collaboration with and feedback from researchers at Japan’s E-Defense facility. 

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2016
Modified by: Shideh Dashti

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Shallow underground structures used for public transportation are a key component of sustainable cities. In dense urban environments, underground structures are often built near tall buildings. Although such buildings have the potential to alter ground motions in their vicinity and transmit significant forces to adjacent underground structures, the impact of these forces are uncertain. The data from centrifuge tests served two purposes: first, to understand seismic soil-structure-underground structure-interaction (SSUSI), and second, to calibrate and improve numerical models. Nonlinear numerical simulations of centrifuge tests helped assess the capabilities of existing numerical tools in capturing SSUSI and key loading mechanisms. A preliminary centrifuge experiment representing free-field soil conditions was first performed with the target soil relative density and the selected input ground motions in the first year of the project. In general, these experiments indicated a notable increase in seismic earth pressures induced on the underground structure adjacent to tall buildings, which must be considered in design. The behavior exhibited in the centrifuge and numerical models in this study are distinctly different than those predicted by many of the common, simplified analysis methods used in engineering design. This indicates that it may be necessary to employ numerical modeling in the design of underground structures in the presence of other structures or with complex geometries and loading conditions. Importantly, modern numerical tools have greatly reduced the barriers to application of large complex numerical modeling in engineering design. This research provides engineers with well-calibrated predictive tools to more reliably characterize interactions between soil, foundation, structure, and shallow underground structure during earthquakes. A better understanding of these interactions will also advance research and practice for a range of underground facilities and critical lifelines including tunnels, pipelines, and utilities. As such, the findings of this project are an important step toward improving the resilience of our urban centers to earthquakes.
